durability you don't have to do anything the data is copied across as you can see
by these pretty little boxes the data is copied across six copies in three AZ's and the database actually reads from any

the copies of the six the fastest one comes back when it does writes it only waits for four of the six to come back
before it declares the transaction committed which means that one of the worst things in database applications is
latency outliers they will kill your apps they will cause you to have connection pile ups and
shall we say poor app behavior by doing this for six quorum we were able to get rid of that not only that a lot of

available and promotable read replicas all sitting on one copy of the storage and so you can stand up up to 15 of them
you can either put them in the same AZ or a different a Z depending on your app infrastructure and because the only
thing Aurora does is it writes redo it never writes a block not once will write a block what that means is that a
transaction that updates one row might be 40 bytes whereas Postgres or Oracle or my sequel
will write a full 8k or 16k block so even though we're writing six copies we
actually do about four times less writing for the same transaction load
now availability is obviously important and as much as I hate to say it things

encrypted columns now DMS could actually transfer an encrypted column but what it
